G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore falls within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and the Property is located in Berkshire County. See Mass. R. Civ. P. 3; G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a landowner or person in control of real property owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to conditions on the premises.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning:
Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and holding that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors regarding conditions on the premises. Although the excerpt provided is from a concurrence discussing trespassers, the majority at 363 Mass. 707–08 expressly adopts a unitary standard of reasonable care for lawful visitors. Thus, the case directly supports the stated proposition as to Massachusetts common law.

(Note: the quoted text is from a concurrence; the relevant holding is in the majority opinion at 707–08.)
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: Because the provided text is from Kaplan, J.’s concurrence and does not contain the majority’s operative holding, the precise language at 363 Mass. 707–08 cannot be quoted here. However, in that portion of the opinion, the court abandons the invitee/licensee distinction and states that an occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to conditions on the premises.

*Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n*,.raw_text: *Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass’n*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 574, 577–78 (2009)
*Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n*,.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and person in control of the Property at 123 Maple Street, owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff, a foreseeable pedestrian using the adjacent public sidewalk, to avoid subjecting her to an unreasonable risk of harm from dangerous conditions arising from the Property, including unsafe trees and branches extending over the sidewalk. See *Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass’n*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 574, 577–78 (2009) (recognizing duty of landowners with respect to conditions that create risks to users of adjacent public ways); *Robbins v. Atkins*, 413 Mass. 436, 437–38 (1992).
*Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass\u2019n*,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a Massachusetts Juvenile Court / care-and-protection/guardianship decision and does not involve premises liability, landowner duties, sidewalks, or dangerous conditions such as trees or branches. It neither mentions nor analyzes duties owed by landowners to pedestrians on adjacent public ways. Accordingly, it does not support the cited proposition regarding a landowner’s duty of reasonable care to sidewalk users, and the citation to Souza for that proposition is inaccurate in this context.

*Robbins v. Atkins*, 413 Mass. 436, 437\.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and person in control of the Property at 123 Maple Street, owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff, a foreseeable pedestrian using the adjacent public sidewalk, to avoid subjecting her to an unreasonable risk of harm from dangerous conditions arising from the Property, including unsafe trees and branches extending over the sidewalk. See *Souza v. Beacon Hill Civic Ass’n*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 574, 577–78 (2009) (recognizing duty of landowners with respect to conditions that create risks to users of adjacent public ways); *Robbins v. Atkins*, 413 Mass. 436, 437–38 (1992).
*Robbins v. Atkins*, 413 Mass. 436, 437\.support_reasoning: Robbins v. Atkins (413 Mass. 436) is not the opinion excerpted here; the provided text is Cambridgeport Savings Bank v. Boersner, a commercial loan/guaranty dispute. This case deals with contract integration, oral modification, reliance, and waiver of defenses by guarantors, and does not address premises liability, duties of landowners to pedestrians, public sidewalks, or dangerous conditions like trees or branches. Accordingly, it does not support the stated proposition about a landowner’s duty to foreseeable pedestrians on adjacent public ways.
*Robbins v. Atkins*, 413 Mass. 436, 437\.relevant_excerpt: What we have here are carefully drawn and comprehensive loan documents which squarely committed Boersner and Puente as full guarantors of the obligations owed by their trust to the plaintiff. The provisions in the guaranties, which integrate closely with the terms of the note and the provisions of the loan agreement, allowed the bank to make accommodations and grant indulgences to the borrowers. Overall, the instruments create a strong barrier against a claim of subsequent modification.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: This duty is consistent with G.L. c. 231, § 85, which provides that negligence in Massachusetts is determined according to what a reasonably prudent person would do under like circumstances.

*Prosser v. Commonwealth*, 398 Mass. 152.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner may be held liable where he knows or reasonably should know that a condition on his property creates a risk of harm to persons outside the premises and fails to take reasonable precautions. See *Prosser v. Commonwealth*, 398 Mass. 152, 155–56 (1986) (recognizing duty to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm to persons using adjacent property or ways); *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731–32 (2000).

*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner may be held liable where he knows or reasonably should know that a condition on his property creates a risk of harm to persons outside the premises and fails to take reasonable precautions. See *Prosser v. Commonwealth*, 398 Mass. 152, 155–56 (1986) (recognizing duty to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm to persons using adjacent property or ways); *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731–32 (2000).
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.support_reasoning: The case does discuss a landowner’s general duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, but it expressly limits that duty to preexisting physical conditions on the land and rejects extending it to dangerous acts or conditions created by third parties (here, guests with fireworks). It does not address, recognize, or affirm any duty owed by a landowner to persons outside the premises, nor does it adopt the Prosser rule about risks to adjacent property or ways. Instead, it narrows landowner liability in the social-host context where the owner did not create, provide, or control the dangerous instrumentality.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The duty of a landowner under general principles of common-law negligence governing dangerous conditions on his land is established. ‘A landowner must act as a reasonable [person] in maintaining . . . property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… The obligation to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition refers to preexisting physical conditions… There is no room in this branch of tort law for the plaintiff’s contention that the fireworks somehow constituted a physical condition on the defendants’ land….”

*Godsoe v. Chicopee*, 335 Mass. 210, 212.proposition: The cracked, drooping branch overhanging the sidewalk was an open and obvious defect which, in light of its location directly above an area used by pedestrians, created an unreasonable and foreseeable risk of harm if not corrected. See *Godsoe v. Chicopee*, 335 Mass. 210, 212–13 (1957) (discussing duty to correct or warn of dangerous conditions where harm is foreseeable).
*Godsoe v. Chicopee*, 335 Mass. 210, 212.case_name: Via v. Asbestos Textile Co. Inc.
*Godsoe v. Chicopee*, 335 Mass. 210, 212.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns recovery of overtime wages, liquidated damages, and attorneys’ fees under the Fair Labor Standards Act and procedural issues regarding appeals and new trials. It does not involve premises liability, open and obvious defects, overhanging branches, sidewalks, or any duty to correct or warn of dangerous conditions. The proposition about a cracked, drooping branch and foreseeable risk of harm is unrelated to the issues decided in this case, so the citation is inaccurate for that purpose.
*Godsoe v. Chicopee*, 335 Mass. 210, 212.relevant_excerpt: "This is an action of contract in which the plaintiff seeks to recover attorney’s fees and for overtime work under the fair labor standards act of 1938, as amended... The only question for us to determine is whether under the law of this Commonwealth the plaintiff is entitled to recover under the pleadings and the specifications. No question of Federal law is involved."

*Dennis v. City of Boston*, 320 Mass. 48.proposition: To the extent Defendant may assert that the storm on July 15, 2023, constituted an “act of God,” such a defense is unavailable where the injury-producing harm results from a combination of natural forces and the defendant’s own negligence, or where ordinary weather is foreseeable. See *Dennis v. City of Boston*, 320 Mass. 48, 50–51 (1946) (act of God defense limited and does not excuse failure to exercise due care against foreseeable natural conditions).
*Dennis v. City of Boston*, 320 Mass. 48.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text concerns an automobile collision, contributory negligence, the judge’s fact-finding, and the power to reconsider and increase damages before final judgment. It does not discuss “act of God,” natural forces, storms, foreseeability of weather, or any limitation on an act-of-God defense. Accordingly, this case, at least as excerpted, does not support the proposition about the unavailability or limitation of an act-of-God defense for combined natural forces and negligence or foreseeable weather conditions.
*Dennis v. City of Boston*, 320 Mass. 48.relevant_excerpt: It may be that when the plaintiff looked to his right and failed to see the defendant’s automobile which must have been in sight, he looked carelessly. But after that the plaintiff made a turn *48 to the left into and completely through the “point of intersection,” all in plain sight of the defendant, who was a substantial distance to the rear. If the plaintiff had seen the defendant when he looked, the plaintiff could nevertheless have been found free from negligence in making the turn as he did.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: The type of harm Plaintiff suffered—being struck by a falling tree branch from a visibly defective limb over a sidewalk during an ordinary storm—is precisely the kind of harm that makes Defendant’s inaction negligent and was entirely foreseeable. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–49 (2006) (foreseeability of risk is central to duty and proximate cause analysis).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The case does stand for the general proposition that reasonable foreseeability of risk is central to both duty and proximate cause analysis, but it does not involve or discuss trees, storms, or premises liability for falling branches. Instead, it concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability that a mentally unstable person with unfettered access would steal a gun and commit violence. Using Jupin to claim that harm from a falling tree limb during an ordinary storm is ‘precisely’ the kind of foreseeable harm making inaction negligent mischaracterizes the case’s facts and holding, even though its general foreseeability language could be analogized.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.… Consequently… ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’… To the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty… it is a test of the ‘reasonable foreseeability’ of the harm.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a negligent defendant is liable for all harm that is reasonably foreseeable, even if the precise manner in which the harm occurs is not predicted in detail. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence that expressly disagrees with the majority’s broader, ‘expanded’ concept of causation and does not itself endorse the foreseeability principle stated in the proposition. While the majority opinion in Poskus may well stand for the idea that a defendant is liable for reasonably foreseeable harms even if the precise manner is not predicted, this specific excerpt neither articulates nor adopts that rule; instead it criticizes the court’s causation approach and only concurs in the narrow foreseeability conclusion about the plaintiff’s injuries. Thus, this opinion text, taken alone, does not support the claimed proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “The court unnecessarily reaches out and declares that our cases involving keys left in ignitions are ‘no longer persuasive,’ ante at 640, because these decisions are inconsistent with our expanded concept of causation. I cannot join this conclusion… I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H.*, 428.raw_text: *Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H.*, 428 Mass. 727, 730 (1999)
*Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H.*, 428.proposition: Plaintiff incurred approximately $3,500 in reasonable and necessary medical expenses for treatment of her injuries. See *Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H.*, 428 Mass. 727, 730 (1999) (recognizing recovery of reasonable medical expenses caused by negligence).
*Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H.*, 428.support_reasoning: The provided text of Peck v. Public Serv. Co. of N.H. concerns criminal convictions for perjury, attempted perjury, wiretap issues, search and seizure, grand jury procedure, materiality, sentencing, and double jeopardy. It does not involve a negligence action, personal injury damages, or any discussion of reasonable and necessary medical expenses. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for recovery of approximately $3,500 in reasonable medical expenses caused by negligence.

*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff lost approximately $600 in wages due to her inability to work for about one week after the injury. See *Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362, 366 (1980) (lost earnings are recoverable as damages in negligence actions).
*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does acknowledge that the plaintiff had wage loss and that wage loss was part of her damages, but it nowhere states or analyzes the general legal principle that lost earnings are recoverable as damages in negligence actions. The only reference is factual (“wage loss of $5,224 for about nine months”), used in assessing excessiveness of the verdict, not as a statement of law. Thus the case is not proper authority for the cited general rule, even though that rule is true as a matter of tort law.
*Griffin v. Gen. Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant points out that the plaintiff proved medical expenses of $24,527 and wage loss of $5,224 for about nine months…. There was evidence to support a finding that there would be substantial loss of earning capacity in the future.”

*Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347,.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and emotional distress associated with her injuries and the incident. See *Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347, 352–53 (6th Cir. 1979) (applying Massachusetts law) (pain and suffering as compensable element of damages); see also *McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 322 Mass. 581, 586 (1948).
*Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347,.case_name: Sharon Proos Kosters v. The Seven-Up Company, & Third Party
*Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with liability theories (negligence, implied warranty, inherently dangerous activity, third‑party beneficiary, etc.) and issues of franchisor responsibility under Michigan law. It does not discuss the types or categories of damages recoverable, nor does it mention pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or emotional distress as compensable elements. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition about compensable pain and suffering damages. The cited pages focus on liability standards, not damages.
*Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347,.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the three instructions we have criticized, taken together, constitute reversible error. The “inherently dangerous activity” instruction and the “opportunity to change design” instruction permitted the jury to hold Seven-Up liable without a finding that the carton was “defective,” contrary to Michigan products liability principles. Neither the law nor the facts justified a “third-party beneficiary” instruction. Although the case was properly submitted to the jury on both negligence and breach of implied warranty theories, there is no way of knowing whether the jury’s verdict was based on one of these theories...

*McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*,.raw_text: *McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 322 Mass. 581, 586 (1948)
*McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*,.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and emotional distress associated with her injuries and the incident. See *Kosters v. Seven-Up Co.*, 595 F.2d 347, 352–53 (6th Cir. 1979) (applying Massachusetts law) (pain and suffering as compensable element of damages); see also *McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 322 Mass. 581, 586 (1948).
*McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*,.support_reasoning: This opinion is a workers’ compensation causation and attorney’s fees case; it does not discuss categories of tort damages such as conscious pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or emotional distress. The only reference to an amount of money relates to attorney’s fees and expenses under the workers’ compensation statute, not to compensable personal injury damages. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition cited.
*McDonald v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: The decree entered in the Superior Court provided for the payment of $750 for attorney’s fees, briefs and other necessary expenses resulting from certification to that court. This provision of the decree follows the phraseology of G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 152, § 11A, inserted by St. 1945, c. 444. That amount was awarded for legal services and expenses rendered in connection with the certification from the board to the Superior Court.

*Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u20.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for her past and future pain and suffering, past and future medical expenses, past wage loss, and any future loss of earning capacity reasonably proven to flow from the incident, as well as any other compensable losses recognized under Massachusetts law. See *Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702–03 (1989).
*Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u20.support_reasoning: Harlow v. Chin is a medical malpractice and damages case, but the quoted pages (702–03) deal with negligence and causation standards, not with the categories of recoverable damages. The opinion elsewhere discusses damages structure (e.g., collateral source offsets, charitable cap, life expectancy, future medical expenses), yet it does not set out the general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover past and future pain and suffering, medical expenses, wage loss, and loss of earning capacity. Thus, it is not appropriate authority for the broad remedial proposition cited.
*Harlow v. Chin*, 405 Mass. 697, 702\u20.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff has met the burden of proving that the defendants' negligence caused the harm he actually suffered.... The medical practitioners would have the plaintiff undergo X-rays... would have the plaintiff undergo a CAT scan.... Early surgical intervention would probably have been successful in preventing quadriplegia." (405 Mass. at 702–03). This discussion concerns causation, not the categories of recoverable damages.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on any judgment for personal injuries at the statutory rate from the date of commencement of this action.
